clinical_study.official_title: The Effect and Safety of Different Sedation Strategies for Diagnostic Bronchoscopy

brief_summary.textblock: Diagnostic bronchoscopy is an invasive procedure performed to diagnose respiratory diseases. But pain has been complained by most of the patients receiving such procedures. Sedation or anesthesia was required by both of the patients and bronchoscopists. Unfortunately, no consensus has been made upon the sedation strategies. Multiple sedation approaches have been applied, such as midazolam and fentanyl, remifentanil and propofol, dexmedetomidine and propofol. The present study was designed to compare these protocols in sedation for diagnostic bronchoscopy.

primary_outcome.time_frame: From the completion of local anesthesia with lidocaine to the completion of bronchoscopy procedure, assessed up to 2 hours
primary_outcome.description: Cough score across the procedure will be classified into 4 degree (1-4) as follows. 1 = none, 2 = one gag or cough only, 3 = >1 gag or cough, but acceptable conditions, 4 = unacceptable conditions

secondary_outcome.time_frame: From the completion of local anesthesia with lidocaine to the completion of bronchoscopy procedure, assessed up to 2 hours
secondary_outcome.description: The numbers of the times of any body movement across the procedure

secondary_outcome.measure: Satisfaction score of the patients and bronchoscopists
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Across the procedure, assessed up to 2 hours
secondary_outcome.description: Satisfaction score of the patients and bronchoscopists regarding to the sedation quality measured by a 0-100 visual analogue scale (VAS). 100 refers to the highest satisfaction degree while 0 refers to the worst satisfaction degree.

secondary_outcome.measure: Amount of the rescue use of propofol
secondary_outcome.time_frame: After sedation induction, assessed up to 2 hours
secondary_outcome.description: The total amount of propofol used as a rescue therapy when the sedation is not deep enough as assessed by the anesthesiologists.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: After termination of the sedation medication, assessed up to 2 hours
secondary_outcome.description: Duration of the recovery from sedation

secondary_outcome.measure: Prevalence of the side effects of respiratory and circulatory system
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Across the sedation duration, assessed up to 2 hours
secondary_outcome.description: The number of the side effects in respiratory and circulatory system during the procedure, including hypertension, hypotension, tackycardia, bradycardia, hypoxia and larynx spasm.

arm_group.description: Sedated with midazolam, dexmedetomidine and remifentanil
Sedated with midazolam, dexmedetomidine and fentanyl
Sedated with midazolam, propofol and remifentanil

intervention.description: Midazolam is used as a common medication for sedation in all groups.
Dexmedetomidine is used for sedation in bronchoscopy with less impact on respiration.
Remifentanil is used for analgesia to prevent bronchoscopy induced cough.
Fentanyl is another opioid drug used for analgesia to prevent bronchoscopy induced cough.
Propofol is used for sedation with high efficacy but more side effect on respiration than dexmedetomidine.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Scheduled for flexible diagnostic bronchoscopy
- Adult patients aged 18 to 65 years
- American Society of Anesthesiologists (ASA) Physical Status Classification I-II
- BMI 18.5-25kg/m2
- Subjects provide informed consent
Exclusion Criteria:
- Severe airway obstruction
- Coagulation disorder
- Repeat bronchoscopy (more than 3 times)
- Severe liver and renal dysfunction
- Cardiovascular and cerebrovascular diseases
- Pregnancy
- Chronic opioid user
- Drug abusers or addicts
